titlepage.publisher:
Michigan Historical Collections
Bentley Historical Library
University of Michigan
titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Jane Lockwood Barney Papers, 1937-2009

did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan, Social Worker, Jane Lockwood Barney, worked for decades in organizations related to aiding the elderly, minorities, homeless, and hungry. Her primary organizations were: Avalon Housing, Inc., Shelter Association of Washtenaw County, St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Washtenaw Housing Alliance, Turner African American Services Council, and the New Hope / University of Michigan Geriatric Clinic (now called the New Hope Outreach Clinic). The collection encompasses material related to Jane Barney's activities after the passing of her husband, Roger Warren Barney, in 1978. The series in the collection are organized by Professional Files and Personal Files. Papers include primarily meeting minutes, professional and personal correspondence, reports, and administrative notes, awards and recognitions, photographs, and family materials.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Donated by Jane Barney (Donor no. 10050) in March and December of 2012.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Jane Lockwood Barney Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan.

bioghist.p: Jane Lockwood Barney was a social and political activist who worked to establish, build, and run a number of organizations aimed to improve the lives of the people of the Ann Arbor area. Her causes included access to high quality health care for minorities and the elderly, homelessness, hunger, job skills training, and Democratic political activism. She attended Wellesley College, Union Theological Seminary, and the University of Michigan School of Social Work.

Jane Lockwood Barney was married to Reverend Roger Warren Barney, and they had three sons and a daughter; Alice B., James O., Jonathan L., and Daniel R. From 1948 to 1967 the family lived at Parishfield, a community devoted to "renewal of the church" where Reverend Barney was one of the three clergy in charge of community management at Parishfield.

Jane Barney was a founder of the Michigan Association of Nursing Home Community Councils, co-founder and President of the Avalon Housing Board, co-Chair of the Turner African American Services Council, and Chair of the Turner Geriatric Clinic Advisory Committee. She served on the Community Development Executive Committee and the boards of the Washtenaw Housing Alliance, Community Council Association, the Housing Bureau for Seniors, and the Shelter Association of Washtenaw County/Ann Arbor. From 1970 to 1989 she worked at the University of Michigan's Institute of Gerontology. After her retirement from the Institute of Gerontology in 1989, she remained active in many organizations and in the Ann Arbor community.

scopecontent.p: The Jane L. Barney papers are comprised of materials documenting her professional and personal life. The Professional Files include organization meeting minutes, correspondence, notes, flyers, manuals, press articles, and personnel files, as well as other administrative papers and reports for the organizations she worked to establish, develop, and run. Also found here are speeches, papers relevant to her work with churches, minorities, and gerontology.

Jane L. Barney's personal papers largely include correspondence with friends, co-workers, politicians, and family, as well as notebooks, diplomas, hospital and assisted living documentation, and photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Professional Files series is divided into nine subseries: Biographical, Avalon Housing, Inc., Shelter Association of Washtenaw County, St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Washtenaw Housing Alliance, Turner African American Services Council, New Hope / University of Michigan Geriatric Clinic (now called the New Hope Outreach Clinic), Projects and Involvement, and Written Works. The series focuses on her involvement and day to day running of the organizations and encompasses her activities from her time as a student to her position at the University of Michigan's Institute of Gerontology.

Papers include organization meeting minutes, correspondence, notes, flyers, manuals, press articles, and personnel files, as well as other administrative papers and reports for the organizations she worked to establish, develop, and run. The Written Works subseries contains papers and articles written by or about Jane Barney. Also found here are speeches, papers relevant to her work with churches, minorities, and gerontology.

scopecontent.p: The Personal Files series is divided into eight subseries: Correspondence, Family, Education, Political Affiliations, Assisted Living, Awards and Recognitions, Photographs, and Miscellaneous. Jane L. Barney's personal papers largely include correspondence with friends, co-workers, politicians, and family. This series also comprises documents from her time as a student at Wellesley College, Union Theological Seminary, and University of Michigan School of Social Work. Notebooks, diplomas, hospital and assisted living documentation, and photographs also are located in this series.

relatedmaterial.head: Related material
relatedmaterial.p: The Roger Warren Barney and Jane Lockwood Barney papers, 1929-2002 (call number 2008125 Aa 2) includes Jane Barney material that was primarily acquired by the Bentley Library with the papers of her husband, Roger Warren Barney, and contains mostly Jane Barney material dated before 1978, the year of Roger Warren Barney's death. Jane Lockwood Barney series (ca. 1.5 linear feet) includes personal files and material related to various organizations. Also included in this collection is family correspondence.
